etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in John Lindley (1799–1865), botanist and horticulturist. From alisma + -ad

definitions: Originally: †(J. Lindleys's name for) a plant of the former family Alismaceae (now Alismataceae), comprising various aquatic and marshland monocotyledonous plants (obsolete). In later use (more widely): any plant of the order Alismatales. Compare alismaceous, alisma.
